Mercedita Ponce Wastewater Pump Station


The Puerto Rico Aqueduct & Sewer Authority (PRASA)  has developed a Risk Management Plan (RMP) for management and prevention of risks associated with the storage and use of chlorine, a regulated toxic substance, at the Mercedita  Pumping station The RMP was prepeared in compliance with 40 CFR Part 68 and Clean Air Act (CAA) Section 112  ( r ) ( 1 ) . The Prevention Elements build upon the facility's Process Safety Management (PSM) System prepared in compliance with CFR 1910.119

Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

It is PRASA's policy to comply with applicable Federal and State requirements.  The chlorination process at the Mercedita Pumping Station uses chlorine, a hazardous toxic substance regulated by EPA, OSHA, PROSHO and EQB.  Due to the hazardous characteristics of chlorine, the Mercedita Pumping Station observes various safety precautions in the storage, conveyance and use of chlorine. The safety precautions are necessary to protect employees, contractors, and visitors at the Mecedita Pumping Station and the inmidiate surounding areas. Safety precautions include procedures and equipment to minimize the potential for accidental release as well as a written emergency program for respose to any chlorine release that may occur.

The Stationary Source and Regulated Substances Handled

The Mercedita Pumping Station pretreats the raw wastewater prior to pump it to the watewater treatment plant. Chlorine is used to treat the water in order to eliminate objectionable odors.

Chlorine is delivered to the facility via truck in one tons container. The maximum inventory of Chlorine is 6,000 pounds. 

Prevention Program

The Prevention Program is composed of many elements and its objective is to prevent accidents and protec the human health, the environment and the property.

Emergency Response Program

PRASA has an emergency response program.  Chlorine gas detectors are located within the storage area fo

r early detection and warning of any leak.  Leak repair kits are kept on site, and operators are trained in how to quickly stop any leak that may occur.  The emergency response program is coordinated with Emergency Management Agency for notification of the public. 

PRASA periodically conducts various training programs, including emergency response training. All PRASA facilities are scheduled to receive refresher training .

Five-year Accident History

Within the past five years, there have been no unplanned releases of chlorine in excess of 10 pounds resulting in injuries or significant property damage on site or known offsite injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage.

Planned Changes to Improve Safety

PRASA uses Process Hazard Analyses (PHA) to identify and recommend changes to ensure a high level of safety.  Issues identified from at PHA are then addressed in PRASA Prevention Program. Recommendations from the most recent PHA include more frequent trainings in operating procedures and emergency response, and an improved maintenance program.
